etymologies: mid 16th century; earliest use found in William Turner (d. 1568), naturalist and religious controversialist. From post-classical Latin sumpsimus, use as noun of classical Latin sūmpsimus, 1st person plural perfect indicative of sūmere to take from sus- + emere to take

definitions: A correct expression, notion, or custom which replaces one that is incorrect but popular or traditional. Contrasted with mumpsimus.
